hedline.hl1: U.S. and Soviet Scientists Plan Joint Studies on Ozone

block.p: LEAD: Scientists from the United States and the Soviet Union will conduct more than 30 joint climate research projects next year, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced today.
LEAD: Scientists from the United States and the Soviet Union will conduct more than 30 joint climate research projects next year, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced today.
Scientists from the United States and the Soviet Union will conduct more than 30 joint climate research projects next year, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced today.
Much of the work will focus on the seasonal depletion of the protective ozone layer over Antarctica, officials said. The ozone layer helps screen out dangerous ultraviolet radiation from the sun.

While the depletion of the ozone layer is not fully understood, many scientists attribute it at least in part to chlorofluorocarbons, chemicals used in aerosol sprays, refrigeration and other applications. The chemicals are believed to break down ozone in the upper atmosphere.
Both the United States and the Soviet Union maintain active scientific bases in Antarctica, from which studies of this damage could be conducted.

Under the agreement calling for the joint climate studies, the two nations will, among other things, coordinate their work in Antarctica, join in developing computer models of the ozone layer and work together in measuring the gas, Federal officials said.
